title: web-codegen: Add extra-traits to syn features
body:
```rust
error[E0277]: `syn::attr::NestedMeta` doesn't implement `std::fmt::Debug`
   --> src/route.rs:149:57
    |
149 |                 attr => panic!("Unknown attribute{:?}", attr),
    |                                                         ^^^^ `syn::attr::NestedMeta` cannot be formatted using `{:?}` because it doesn't implement `std::fmt::Debug`
    |
    = help: the trait `std::fmt::Debug` is not implemented for `syn::attr::NestedMeta`
    = note: required because of the requirements on the impl of `std::fmt::Debug` for `&syn::attr::NestedMeta`
    = note: required by `std::fmt::Debug::fmt`
```

title: Don't DISCONNECT from stream when reader is empty
body:
This should fix #868 

The issue seemed to be that `read_available` would return `true` when nothing has been read from the stream, which disconnects the connection. However, for chunked transfers, it could be that nothing is read from the stream at some point (?)

title: Add Migration steps for Custom Error
body: Adds migration steps for custom error in 1.0

title: Fix Logger time format (use rfc3339)
body:
The current implementation of Logger middleware logs the following for `"%t"` log format:

```bash
TmFmt { tm: Tm { tm_sec: 36, tm_min: 0, tm_hour: 17, tm_mday: 27, tm_mon: 4, tm_year: 119, tm_wday: 1, tm_yday: 146, tm_isdst: 1, tm_utcoff: 7200, tm_nsec: 149522000 }, format: Str("[%d/%b/%Y:%H:%M:%S %z]") }
```

This PR fixes this behavior and uses `rfc3339` format.

I am not entirely sure if we are Ok with rfc3339 or we need to keep the Nginx like access log time format (`%d/%b/%Y:%H:%M:%S %z`). If so, I will adjust the PR to use it.

title: added docs for wrap and wrap_fn
Expand codegen to allow specify guards and async
body:
Route's attributes:

- `"path"` - Raw literal string with path for which to register handler
- `async` - Attribute to indicate that registered function is asynchronous.
- `guard="function_name"` - Registers function as guard using `actix_web::guard::fn_guard`

If resource type is not specified, attempts to infer it based on return type (if it fails, assume regular function)

title: Support to set header names of `ClientRequest` as Camel-Case
body:
This is the case for supporting to request for servers which don't perfectly implement the `RFC 7230`. It is important for an app which uses `ClientRequest` as core part.

Because `http` crate will have no plans to support the Camel-Case headers, ([see](https://github.com/hyperium/http/issues/228#issuecomment-404996750)), We need to add an option to support it, as `hyper` [did](https://github.com/hyperium/http/issues/228#issuecomment-404996755).

So, I implement this case, as following.

* Add field `upper_camel_case_headers` to `ClientRequest`.

* Add function `set_upper_camel_case_headers` to `ClientRequest`
  and `ClientRequestBuilder` to set field `upper_camel_case_headers`.
  `true` is for turning on Camel-Case headers.
  `false` to disable it.
  Default is `false`.

* Add trait `client::writer::UpperCamelCaseHeader` for
  `http::header::HeaderName`, let it can be converted to Camel-Case
  then writed to buffer.

* Add test `test_client::test_upper_camel_case_headers`.

title: httpresponse: add constructor for HttpResponseBuilder
body:
This adds a constructor for `HttpResponseBuilder`, parametrized on
status code. It allows to directly build a response builder in a
conditional way. The usecase is for consumers where the response status
code is not statically known but received as an external parameter
instead.

body:
The original
> This method requires to run within properly configured Actix system.

was not correct, so merged it with the previous statement about panicking (since it panics for me if I try to launch it /wo an actix system).

Could alternatively be
> This method requires a properly configured Actix system.

or a number of similar variants if the behaviour when run without an Actix system must remain undefined.

_PS this is my first contribution to this project, let me know if I should do something extra, like updating the CHANGES.md (assuming that my changes are OK :))_

title: Add io handling for ECONNRESET when data has already been received
body:
I came across a case, in a project where I'm using the actix_web client, where the remote http server would close the connection immediately after sending the response. This would cause the client to get the data, but then get an ECONNRESET resulting in a failed transaction. Because the response was fully received, the io layer should return that it received data and the stream has closed.

Here is the strace of the issue where both the client and server are in the same process. PID 2148 is the server, PID 2147 is the actix_web::client. The server sends all the data, then closes the connection, the client receives all the data and on the next poll gets an ECONNRESET.

```
[pid  2148] sendto(4, "HTTP/1.1 200 OK\r\nConnection: clo"..., 2616, MSG_NOSIGNAL, NULL, 0) = 2616
[pid  2147] <... epoll_wait resumed> [{EPOLLIN|EPOLLOUT, {u32=4194305, u64=4194305}}], 1024, 941) = 1
[pid  2148] close(4 <unfinished ...>
[pid  2147] recvfrom(9,  <unfinished ...>
[pid  2148] <... close resumed> )       = 0
[pid  2147] <... recvfrom resumed> "HTTP/1.1 200 OK\r\nConnection: clo"..., 32768, 0, NULL, NULL) = 2616
[pid  2147] recvfrom(9, 0x7f2dafd2cbb8, 30152, 0, NULL, NULL) = -1 ECONNRESET (Connection reset by peer)
```

This patch could be changed to use a match expression if needed.

title: Use NamedFile with an existing File
body:
Resolves #659.

This adds `NamedFile::from_file` and `NamedFile::from_file_with_config` next to the usual `NamedFile::open` and `NamedFile::open_with_config`.

I have included documentation and an example/doctest for both methods.

Sends a `actix::actors::signal::SignalType::Term` signal to the TestServer's backend when dropped to prevent leaking listener threads in tests. 

Fixes https://github.com/actix/actix-web/issues/654

title: Improve change askama_escape in favor of v_htmlescape
body: Improves the performance losses of false positives (all no html escapable between ascii 34 and 62) and adds support for SIMD. [Benches on Travis](https://travis-ci.org/rust-iendo/v_htmlescape/jobs/472791580#L688)

title: show index if index file doesn't exist
body: Currently, `show_index` is completely ignored if `index_file` is set. It's saner to show index if the designated index file doesn't exist.

title: Add with-cookie init-method for TestRequest
Only return a single Origin value
body:
Browsers do not accept a list of origins in the A-C-A-O header [1] [2] [3]. This pull request returns only a single origin if a match was found.

fixes #603.

[1] https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/CORS/Errors/CORSMultipleAllowOriginNotAllowed
[2] https://www.w3.org/TR/cors/#access-control-allow-origin-response-header
[3] https://cs.chromium.org/chromium/src/services/network/cross_origin_read_blocking.cc?sq=package:chromium&dr=C&g=0&l=245-266

title: Add static lifetime requirements in StaticFileConfig trait (0.8)
body:
I've been looking into actix-web 0.8; recently I found that the StaticFiles API was updated in #604. Before, the `default_handler` method took a `Handler` as an argument, such as [this 404 handler](https://github.com/actix/examples/blob/master/basics/src/main.rs#L49) from the basic actix-web example -- I could just pass `.default_handler(p404)` and it would work fine.

In the 0.8 branch, aside from turning into a trait method, the params for [`default_handler`](https://github.com/actix/actix-web/commit/580dcb8d6fae9276f739b2acfa1c33d47bae7328#diff-b45d845f139c97025a9348344f529958R119) were changed slightly, and I couldn't find a way to modify that handler function accordingly. My best guess was to call `p404(req).unwrap().respond_to(req).into()` in the new trait method, but I got an error saying "the parameter type `S` may not live long enough so that the type `S` will meet its required lifetime bounds". The compiler recommended adding an explicit `'static` lifetime bound on `S`, which wasn't compatible with the `StaticFileConfig` trait definition.

This change makes the above adaptation work as expected.

title: Store visit and login timestamp as well as peer address in the identity cookie
body: Currently if cookie is leaked the only method of revoking it is to change the key (`max-age` is settable but it is still possible to get cookie from browser cache). This change allows the developer to specify the deadlines after which the cookie is no longer accepted
